description.waterInstruction: Like other succulents, String of Pearls requires little water. If your String of Pearls gets too much water, it can develop root rot, which is often fatal to the plant.
The top soil should be dry before watering again. If the soil is still moist, you risk giving the plant too much water and it can rot.
All the soil should be dry before watering again. If the soil is still moist, you risk giving your Aloe too much water which can make it start to rot.
All the soil should be dry before watering again. If the soil is still moist, you risk giving your snake plant too much water which can make it start to rot.
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving the Monstera more water.

description.otherNames: Dypsis lutescens, Bamboo Palm, Golden Cane Palm
description.waterInstruction: Feel the soil: it can be slightly dry to a bit moist but not wet when watering it again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers, if water seeps out its still wet.
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving your philodendron more water.
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving more water. If the soil is still wet, you risk giving the plant too much water and it can rot.
All the soil should be dry before watering again. If the soil still is moist, you risk giving the plant too much water and it can rot.

Strelitzia likes moisture but doesn’t want to stay wet during a long time so it can actually needs a soil that drains well and can withhold water at the same time. It’s also important that it’s planted in a pot with drainage holes. If  all this is done properly but it still doesn’t dry up: make sure that it gets enough light ( at least 6 hours of sunlight each day).
All the soil should be dry before watering again. If the soil is still moist, you risk giving your Cactus too much water which can make it start to rot
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving more water. If the soil is still wet, you risk giving your Benjamin Fig too much water and it can rot.

Feel the soil: the top layer of soil can be slightly dry and the soil below should be a bit moist, but not wet, when watering your Common Ivy again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers - if water seeps out it's still wet.
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving your Dragon Tree more water. Dragon Tree are somewhat drought-tolerant, so you don't need to stress about them drying up a bit.

Feel the soil: the top layer of soil can be slightly dry and the soil below should be a bit moist, but not wet, when watering your Spider Plant again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers - if water seeps out it's still wet.

Feel the soil: the top layer (about 2 inches) should be dry before giving your Guiana Chestnut more water

Basil really loves water and does not like to dry up! It's hard to overwater it, but even a water-loving plant can get too much water. Always feel the soil before watering - it should feel damp but not wet.
Feel the soil: it should be a bit moist but not wet when watering your Silver Inch Plant again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers - if water seeps out, it's still wet.
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving your Monkey Mask more water. Monkey Mask are somewhat drought-tolerant, so you don't need to stress about them drying up a bit.
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 2 inches) should be dry before giving your False Christmas Cactus more water
Check the potting mix - if it looks dry and maybe a bit dusty, it might be time to water. You can also lift up the pot to check its weight, if it feels too light it's time to water your Orchid
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving your Money Plant more water. Money Plant are somewhat drought-tolerant, so you don't need to stress about them drying up a bit.

description.cleaningInstruction: Clean leaves every Change depend on season month
description.waterInstruction: Citrus love water and do not like to dry out completely. Feel the top soil: it can be slightly dry to a bit moist, but not wet, when watering it again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers - if water seeps out it's still wet. The only time they don't want a lot of water is in winter if they are being overwintered, you should then let the soil dry out slightly before watering again.

Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inches) should be dry before giving your Pineapple more water. You should also check the rosette/center of the plant, it should always have at least a little water in it.
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving more water. If the soil is still wet, you risk giving your Cast Iron Plant too much water and it can rot.
Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inch) should be dry before giving more water. If the soil is still wet, you risk giving your Fishtail Palm too much water and it can rot.
All the soil should be dry before watering again. If the soil is still moist, you risk giving your Pickle plant too much water which can make it start to rot

Feel the soil: the top layer of soil can be slightly dry and the soil below should be a bit moist, but not wet, when watering your Banana plant again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers - if water seeps out it's still wet.

Feel the soil: the top layer of soil can be slightly dry and the soil below should be a bit moist, but not wet, when watering your Poinsettia again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers - if water seeps out it's still wet.

Feel the soil: the top layer (about 1 inches) should be dry before giving your Guzmania more water. You should also check the rosette/center of the plant, it should always have at least a little water in it.

Feel the soil: the top layer of soil can be slightly dry and the soil below should be a bit moist, but not wet, when watering your Hydrangea again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers - if water seeps out it's still wet.

Golden polypody love water and do not like to dry out completely. Feel the top soil: it can be slightly dry to a bit moist, but not wet, when watering it again. Squeeze a bit of soil between your fingers - if water seeps out it's still wet. The only time they don't want a lot of water is in winter if they are being overwintered, you should then let the soil dry out slightly before watering again.
